channel.title: Energy & Environment
channel.description: News, Analysis and Opinion from POLITICO

item.title: Trump: US will sell 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil
item.description: The president said he would personally control the proceeds from the sales to ensure they are being used to “benefit the people of Venezuela and the United States.”

media:content.media:title: Evana, an oil tanker, is docked at El Palito port in Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, on Dec. 21, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By James Bikales

item.title: Trump to meet with oil execs about Venezuela on Friday
item.description: "Oil companies will be looking for security guarantees" — and have questions about "an election which restores a government that respects the rule of law," one person familiar with the gathering said.

media:content.media:title: A resident walks past a mural featuring oil pumps and wells in Caracas, Venezuela, on Tuesday.

item.dc:creator: By Ben Lefebvre, Zack Colman and Sophia Cai
item.dc:contributor: By Ben Lefebvre, Zack Colman and Sophia Cai

item.title: Trump administration launches new bid to pressure US oil companies on Venezuela
item.description: The president’s Energy and Interior secretaries are joining the effort to cajole the petroleum businesses to invest in the country’s shattered oil fields

media:content.media:title: A man wipes his tears while holding flags of Venezuela and the United States next to the statue of Simon Bolivar in Bolívar Square on Saturday in Bogotá, Colombia.

item.dc:creator: By Ben Lefebvre, Zack Colman and James Bikales
item.dc:contributor: By Ben Lefebvre, Zack Colman and James Bikales

item.title: Trump, atoms, AI and the Texas data center gusher
item.description: Fermi America wants to build a massive private nuclear-powered energy grid for artificial intelligence. Can the brassy avatar of Trump’s risk-taking tech economy survive?

media:content.media:credit: Photos by Ramsay de Give for POLITICO
media:content.media:title: An aerial view of the Fermi America construction site in Amarillo, Texas, on Dec. 9.

item.dc:creator: By Jason Plautz

item.title: Trump admin sends tough private message to oil companies on Venezuela
item.description: The White House has told companies they must rebuild Venezuela's crude-pumping infrastructure if they want compensation for assets seized by Caracas.

media:content.media:title: Evana, an oil tanker, is docked at El Palito port in Puerto Cabello, Venezuela, Dec. 21, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Ben Lefebvre, Zack Colman and James Bikales
item.dc:contributor: By Ben Lefebvre, Zack Colman and James Bikales

item.title: Betting on climate failure, these investors could earn billions
item.description: Investment firms have put over $100 million into developing risky technologies that could cool the planet with unknown side effects.

media:content.media:title: Venture capitalists have increased their investments in technologies that would alter the atmosphere to reduce global warming.

item.dc:creator: By Corbin Hiar

item.title: ‘Incredibly reckless’: Trump’s wind halt stuns even some allies
item.description: Republican worries about energy affordability didn’t deter the administration from halting five major projects that had already begun construction.

media:content.media:title: Wind turbine bases, generators and blades are seen at the staging area for Dominion Energy’s wind turbine project on Dec. 22 in Portsmouth, Virginia.

item.dc:creator: By Benjamin Storrow and Kelsey Tamborrino
item.dc:contributor: By Benjamin Storrow and Kelsey Tamborrino

item.title: Senate Democrats cut off permitting talks after Trump’s newest ‘assault’ on wind
item.description: The Trump administration’s blocking of renewable projects is putting in jeopardy the long-running talks to reduce red tape for energy projects.

media:content.media:title: Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.) walks to a meeting at the U.S. Capitol on Dec. 8, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Josh Siegel and Kelsey Tamborrino
item.dc:contributor: By Josh Siegel and Kelsey Tamborrino

item.title: Trump administration halts offshore wind projects from Virginia to New England, in major blow to clean power
item.description: The move is yet another escalation from President Donald Trump, who has vowed to throttle wind projects despite his party's worries about electricity affordability.

media:content.media:title: Wind turbines operate at Vineyard Wind 1 offshore wind farm off the coast of Massachusetts.

item.dc:creator: By Kelsey Tamborrino and Benjamin Storrow
item.dc:contributor: By Kelsey Tamborrino and Benjamin Storrow

item.title: The US has a power crunch. Congress is still far from solving it.
item.description: A House-passed bill aimed at speeding approvals of energy projects includes language that wind and solar supporters call unacceptable. Now it goes to the Senate.

media:content.media:title: Democrats have focused their permitting efforts on smoothing approvals for interstate power lines that could send wind or solar energy over long distances.

item.dc:creator: By Josh Siegel

item.title: The fight over the Colorado River has become a political nightmare
item.description: The Trump administration is stuck between two key political swing states and two of the nation’s reddest as they duke it out over access to the West’s most important river.

media:content.media:title: A bathtub ring of light minerals shows the high water line of Lake Mead near water intakes on the Arizona side of Hoover Dam at the Lake Mead National Recreation Area on June 26, 2022, near Boulder City, Nevada.

item.dc:creator: By Annie Snider

item.title: Not a ‘game changer’: What to know about Trump’s nuclear fusion deal
item.description: A merger between Truth Social’s parent company and the fusion venture TAE Technologies is the latest big-money bet on an energy source that may be decades from delivering results.

media:content.media:title: The download screen for the Truth Social app is seen on a laptop computer on March 20, 2024, in New York.

item.dc:creator: By Christa Marshall

item.title: Trump officials dive into the West’s biggest water war
item.description: Interior officials are losing their patience with states as the West’s most important river teeters on the brink of crisis.

media:content.media:title: Colorado River water users are meeting in Las Vegas this week.

item.dc:creator: By Annie Snider

item.title: Trump administration asking US oil industry to return to Venezuela — but getting no takers
item.description: The administration’s outreach to the industry, previously unreported, is the latest sign the White House is dreaming of a post-Maduro future for Venezuela.

media:content.media:title: Members of the audience wave Venezuelan and American flags as President Donald Trump speaks to a Venezuelan American community at Florida International University in Miami on Feb. 18, 2019, to speak out against President Nicolas Maduro.

item.dc:creator: By Ben Lefebvre, Sophia Cai and James Bikales
item.dc:contributor: By Ben Lefebvre, Sophia Cai and James Bikales

item.title: Trump’s dismantling of climate research center is a ‘destruction of knowledge,’ critics say
item.description: The White House says it’s targeting the “premier research stronghold for left-wing climate lunacy.”

media:content.media:title: Office of Management and Budget Director Russ Vought departs a Senate Republican Conference luncheon at the U.S. Capitol on July 15.

item.dc:creator: By Robin Bravender

item.title: Vought says National Center for Atmospheric Research will be dismantled
item.description: Loss of the program would mean “public safety is at risk and science is being attacked,” Colorado Gov. Jared Polis (D) said in a statement Tuesday.

media:content.media:title: OMB Director Russ Vought speaks to reporters in the Capitol in July.

item.dc:creator: By Gregory Svirnovskiy

item.title: The brawl over the Colorado River is about more than water
item.description: The lifeblood of the West is drying up — and scrambling state and local politics.

media:content.media:title: The Colorado River winds its way along the West Rim of the Grand Canyon.

item.dc:creator: By Annie Snider

item.title: Vote to overhaul FEMA canceled after leaked report
item.description: The FEMA Review Council was scheduled to approve its recommendations for overhauling the agency Thursday.

media:content.media:title: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem is overseeing an overhaul of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

item.dc:creator: By Thomas Frank

item.title: ‘Windmills are a disgrace’: Inside Trump’s war against a growing US industry
item.description: Efforts to avoid conflict and seek help from GOP moderates didn't spare wind companies from the president's attacks.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Claudine Hellmuth/POLITICO (source images via AP)
media:content.media:title: "Many of us knew that if Trump won, we were dead,” one former wind executive said. But another industry leader expressed surprise at "the level of aggression and opposition that the administration launched on Day One."

item.dc:creator: By Benjamin Storrow, Kelsey Tamborrino and Jessie Blaeser
item.dc:contributor: By Benjamin Storrow, Kelsey Tamborrino and Jessie Blaeser

item.title: US seizes Cuba-bound Venezuelan oil tanker, ramping up pressure on Maduro
item.description: The seizure off the Venezuelan coast is a major escalation of U.S. aggression toward the South American nation.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump speaks to a Venezuelan American community at the Florida Ocean Bank Convocation Center in Miami in 2019.

item.dc:creator: By Eric Bazail-Eimil and James Bikales
item.dc:contributor: By Eric Bazail-Eimil and James Bikales

item.title: Electricity prices jump after Trump rejects disaster aid for Michigan utilities
item.description: The president denied the state’s request for federal aid to rebuild power lines after a fierce ice storm last March, a move that could force thousands of rural electricity customers to pay the entire tab.

media:content.media:title: A utility worker repairs lines after an ice storm in Michigan in 2023.

item.dc:creator: By Thomas Frank

item.title: Pollution from coal plants was dropping. Then came Trump and AI.
item.description: Data centers’ hunger for electricity is prompting some states to keep their coal-burning power plants from closing — while DC relaxes air pollution limits.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Claudine Hellmuth/POLITICO (source images via iStock)
media:content.media:title: CW_Wittenberg_AI_COAL_2000_01.jpg

item.dc:creator: By Ariel Wittenberg

item.title: The world is fractured. The climate talks reflected that.
item.description: Delegates from nearly 200 nations — not including the U.S. — showed they could make some progress. But they deferred the hardest decisions.

media:content.media:title: Colombian representative Daniela Durán González (left) gestures during Saturday's closing session of the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, which included sniping among delegates from developed and developing countries.

item.dc:creator: By Zack Colman, Karl Mathiesen, Zia Weise and Sara Schonhardt
item.dc:contributor: By Zack Colman, Karl Mathiesen, Zia Weise and Sara Schonhardt

item.title: Trump refused to send disaster aid to Chicago after 2 devastating storms
item.description: The destruction caused by the summer storms was enough that past presidents likely would have approved requests for federal assistance, former FEMA officials said.

media:content.media:title: Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker meets with former military generals and admirals on Oct. 16 in Chicago.

item.dc:creator: By Thomas Frank

item.title: Deal or ‘meh’ deal? Climate summit ends on a deflating note
item.description: Nearly two weeks of talks in the Amazon ended with commitments to do more, but no firm movement on the most divisive issues — including turning away from fossil fuels.

media:content.media:title: Indigenous activists protested inside the COP30 climate summit venue a day before delegates approved Saturday's agreement in Belém, Brazil.

item.dc:creator: By Sara Schonhardt, Karl Mathiesen, Zia Weise and Zack Colman
item.dc:contributor: By Sara Schonhardt, Karl Mathiesen, Zia Weise and Zack Colman

item.title: Inside Greenpeace USA's fight for its life
item.description: The environmental group is grappling with leadership turnover and staff cuts as it fights an energy company in court.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Claudine Hellmuth/POLITICO (source images via iStock)
media:content.media:title: GW_Bravender_GREENPEACE_2000_01.jpg

item.dc:creator: By Robin Bravender

item.title: Climate summit proposal dodges call to accelerate move from fossil fuels
item.description: The final text of a proposed deal would be a disappointment for European countries and low-lying Pacific island nations.

media:content.media:title: Activists hang banners while protesting Friday at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil.

item.dc:creator: By Karl Mathiesen

item.title: It’s official: Turkey will be boss of COP31 climate talks
item.description: And its rival Australia will play a role in running the negotiations.

media:content.media:title: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan’s government won a more than year-long struggle with Australia for the right to host next year's U.N. climate summit.

item.dc:creator: By Karl Mathiesen

item.title: EU threatens to block ‘weak’ COP30 deal
item.description: The bloc and its allies raged at a draft agreement presented by the Brazilian hosts on Friday morning.

media:content.media:title: Attendees at a plenary session Friday listen to COP30 President André Aranha Corrêa do Lago, who pleaded that "this cannot be an agenda that divides us."

item.dc:creator: By Zia Weise, Karl Mathiesen, Sara Schonhardt and Zack Colman
item.dc:contributor: By Zia Weise, Karl Mathiesen, Sara Schonhardt and Zack Colman

item.title: Fire disrupts climate talks — and souvenir hunters
item.description: The blaze closed an area of the venue that hosted pavilions set up by countries to showcase their climate actions. China’s knicknacks were especially popular.

media:content.media:title: The China Pavilion at COP30.

item.dc:creator: By Sara Schonhardt
